Key Arguments: The bill creates two classes of citizens, disproportionately affecting regular citizens with fines and restrictions.
The legislation risks stifling democratic power by imposing excessive constraints on speech.
Determining what is true or untrue is challenging due to the evolving nature of information.
The bill targets not only false information but also true information deemed misleading, undermining freedom of speech.
Industry bodies influenced by large players may create anti-competitive practices.
The bill's extraterritorial application is impractical and contradicts Australia's stance against extraterritoriality.
The legislation suppresses diverse viewpoints, particularly those of marginalized groups.
The bill imposes undue interference and threats on digital platforms and users, suppressing free expression.
Notable Quotes: The bill, as it currently stands, creates two distinct classes of citizens...
The internet has been a remarkable tool for democratizing information...
The ever-evolving nature of information means that what was once widely accepted fact can be contradicted later.
Freedom of speech allows for open and honest discussions, even when individuals may be wrong...
Restrictive regulations imposed by this bill could hinder the organic competition that is currently taking place.
The proposed bill also contradicts Australia's stance against extraterritoriality...
